BIM is a process that involves creating and managing a digital representation of a building's physical and functional characteristics. Your vehicle’s engine relies on the lubrication provided by oil to function properly. Oil helps to cool the engine, reduce friction, and prevent wear and tear on engine components. Over time, the oil in your vehicle will break down and become dirty, which can affect its ability to lubricate and cool the engine. Regular oil changes are essential for keeping your engine in good condition and ensuring long-term performance.

Have you heard about NFTs but aren’t sure what they are? You’re not alone. NFTs, or non-fungible tokens, are a relatively new type of digital asset that can represent anything from artwork to collectible items. In this ultimate guide to NFTs, we’ll explain what they are, how they work, and how you can use them in your business or personal life.
What are NFTs?
NFTs, or non-fungible tokens, are unique digital assets that are stored on a blockchain. Unlike cryptocurrencies, which are interchangeable and can be exchanged for other assets, NFTs are one-of-a-kind and cannot be exchanged for other assets.
Because NFTs are stored on a blockchain, they are immutable and tamper-proof. This makes them ideal for storing unique digital assets such as artwork, collectibles, and virtual real estate.
How do NFTs work?
NFTs work by using cryptography to create a unique identifier for each asset. This identifier is stored on a blockchain, which is a decentralized and tamper-proof ledger of all NFTs. When you own an NFT, you have sole custody of it and can prove ownership through

I'<s>I know this may seem a bit silly, but I've always been intrigued by the concept of time. I know, I know, it's a pretty abstract thing to be interested in, but bear with me for a moment.
For those of you who may not be familiar with the idea, time is a concept that helps us to understand and organize the events that occur around us. We use it to measure the duration between two events, to schedule our daily activities, and to plan for the future.
But have you ever stopped to think about what time really is? Is it something that exists independently of us? Or is it simply a way that we categorize and make sense of the world around us?
If time is simply a human construct, then it stands to reason that there are an infinite number of ways in which we could conceive of and organize time. After all, there are an infinite number of possible ways to categorize and understand the events that occur in the world.
So why do we use the way that we do? Is it simply because it's the way that we've always used it? Or is there some deeper, underlying reason that we've been unable to fully understand?
I suppose that's what fascinates me about time. It's such a fundamental aspect of our lives, and yet it's so difficult to truly grasp and understand.

Posted on January 27, 2016 by Mark Aldrich
If there is a bright side to being a pessimist, I haven’t found it yet.
For the longest time, I was of the belief that being an optimist was a preferable attitude. Being positive, hopeful, and having a “can-do” attitude seemed like a good way to approach life. It seemed to make sense that the glass was half-full rather than half-empty, that one should find the silver lining in every cloud, and that the best things in life are free.
But as I’ve gotten older, I’ve come to realize that there is a downside to optimism. It can be naivete, it can blind us to reality, and it can make us vulnerable to being taken advantage of.
When you’re an optimist, you believe that things will work out in the end, that the universe will align itself to your benefit, and that good things are on the way. This is all well and good when things are going well, but when they’re not, being an optimist can be detrimental.
Pessimism, on the other hand, has a reputation for being a negative and depressing outlook on life.

Jeanette C. Carlson, 94
July 20, 2017 By News Staff
Jeanette C. Carlson, 94, a longtime Milton-Freewater, Oregon resident, died July 15, 2017, at the Walla Walla Care Center.
Jeanette was born Aug. 29, 1922, in Portland, Ore., to Fred and Mabel (Harris) Carlson. She grew up in Portland and attended school there.
On June 2, 1942, Jeanette married Lester “Bill” Carlson in Portland. The couple farmed in the Milton-Freewater area for many years before retiring in 1980 and moving to Walla Walla.
Jeanette was a homemaker and a member of the United Methodist Church in Milton-Freewater. She enjoyed gardening, canning and cooking, and was known for her delicious apple pies.

Peter A. Gourevitch
In this controversial and insightful book, one of the most prominent economists of our time argues that the case for free trade has been oversold. Over the past few decades, free trade has become the dominant economic policy around the world. Supporters of free trade argue that it leads to increased economic growth, higher living standards, and improved opportunities for all. But as Peter Gourevitch argues, the evidence for these claims is far from clear.
In The Case Against Free Trade, Gourevitch presents a passionate and compelling case against free trade policies. Drawing on a wide range of economic theory and evidence from around the world, he argues that free trade has actually led to increased income inequality, the loss of jobs and industries, and the exploitation of workers and the environment. He also shows that the benefits of free trade for the majority of people are outweighed by the costs, and that a more balanced approach to economic policy is needed.
With its clear and accessible writing, The Case Against Free Trade will be essential reading for anyone interested in the future of the global economy. It is a thought-provoking and timely contribution to one of the most important debates of our time.
